questions.text: An intern was asked to give an intravenous injection to a vein in the cubital fossa. All the following are true about the cubital fossa, except _________.

choices.text: Musculocutaneous nerve is one of the contents
Radial nerve enters the fossa laterally
Median cubital vein forms the roof

questions.solution:
All the above statements are true about the cubital fossa, except the musculocutaneous nerve is one of the contents.

The cubital fossa is a triangular depression present in the anterior side of the elbow joint. The boundaries of the cubital fossa include:

  • Medially: Lateral border of the pronator teres.
  • Laterally: Medial border of the brachioradialis. (option A)
  • Base: Proximally by an imaginary line joining the epicondyles of the humerus.
  • Apex (pointed downward): Joining of the lateral and medial boundaries.
  • Roof: Skin, superficial fascia containing median cubital vein (option D) joining the cephalic and basilic veins, lateral cutaneous nerve of the forearm, medial cutaneous nerve of the forearm, bicipital aponeurosis, and deep fascia.
  • Floor: Brachialis and supinator muscles.

The contents of the brachial fossa are (from medial to lateral side):

  • Median nerve
  • Brachial artery, terminating into radial and ulnar arteries
  • Biceps brachii tendon with the bicipital aponeurosis
  • Radial nerve enters the fossa laterally (option C) in the groove between the brachialis and brachioradialis

Clinical significance:

  • The median cubital vein is the most commonly preferred vein of choice for intravenous injections. 
  • Auscultation of the brachial artery in front of the elbow helps in measuring the blood pressure.

questions.text: C wave of JVP represents:

choices.text: Tricuspid bulge into right atrium during isovolumetric ventricular contraction

questions.solution:
'C' wave in JVP represents tricuspid bulge into right atrium during isovolumetric ventricular contraction.

Characteristics of JVP :

  • a wave corresponds to atrial systole which causes regurgitation of some blood into the great veins.
  • c wave occurs due to the increase in atrial pressure caused by bulging of the tricuspid valve into the right atrium during isovolumetric ventricular contraction.
  • x descent occurs due to the fall in atrial pressure during ventricular systole due to pulling of valve leaflets.
  • v wave is seen at the end of ventricular contraction and occurs due to the slow venous filling which causes an increase in atrial pressure.
  • y descent occurs due to the passive emptying of the right atrium into the right ventricle.

questions.text:
A patient presented with tendon xanthomas. His lipid profile showed serum cholesterol levels to be 283 mg/dL and serum LDL to be 202 mg/dL. He was started on lovastatin. What is the likely diagnosis?

LDL - Low density lipoprotein
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation with tendon xanthomas and elevated serum LDL (low-density lipoprotein) and elevated serum cholesterol points to a diagnosis of familial hypercholesterolemia (FH).

Familial hypercholesterolemia  (type IIa hyperlipoproteinemia) is an inherited disorder due to defects in LDL receptors. This defect causes a decrease in the uptake of LDL and cholesterol. As a result, the blood levels of both LDL and cholesterol are elevated. Such patients are at increased risk to develop atherosclerosis and coronary artery disease.

Features of FH: 

  • Painful polyarthritis and tendinitis are common.
  • Physical findings seen are corneal arcus and tendon xanthomas over Achilles tendon and the dorsum of hands. Xanthomas are tumorous masses produced by foamy cell clusters (lipid-laden macrophages) found in the connective tissue of the skin and in tendons.

Diagnosis is done clinically based on hypercholesterolemia with 

  • LDL > 190 mg/dl, 
  • Family history of hypercholesterolemia and/or
  • Premature coronary artery disease.

Treatment includes lifestyle changes, restriction of a fatty diet, and pharmacotherapy with statins in heterozygous FH patients.

Recent drugs for specific treatment of homozygous FH are:

  • Lomitapide, a microsomal triglyceride transfer protein (MTP) inhibitor, and
  • Mipomersen, an antisense oligonucleotide against apoB.

The image below shows Achilles tendon xanthoma and a plain lateral radiograph of both ankles showing bilateral symmetrical swellings (arrows) superior to the calcaneum respectively.

 

 

Other options

Option B: Tangier’s disease is a hypolipoproteinemia caused by a mutation of the ABCA1 gene. Enlarged orange tonsils are pathognomonic. Low HDL levels are seen. There is an increased risk for atherosclerosis.

The image below shows enlarged yellow-orange colored tonsils in Tangier's disease.

 

Option C: Lipoprotein lipase (LPL) deficiency causes type I hyperlipoproteinemia due to defects in LPL or apo C-II. Eruptive xanthomas are seen. Chylomicrons and VLDL are elevated. LDL and HDL are low. There is no risk for coronary disease.

Option D: Familial hyperchylomicronemia syndrome is caused due to either LPL deficiency, ApoC-II deficiency, ApoA-V deficiency, or GPIHBP1 mutation. Clinically, patients present with recurrent episodes of severe abdominal pain due to acute pancreatitis. The retinal blood vessels may be opalescent and are called lipemia retinalis. Increased levels of triglycerides (mostly >1000 mg/dL) is seen. The risk of premature coronary heart disease is low.

questions.text: A 73-year-old woman presents with chronic fatigue and easy bruising. She has had surgery for ovarian cancer 7 years ago along with chemoradiation. Her lab reports reveal pancytopenia and bone marrow biopsy shows the following finding. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of therapy-related myelodysplastic syndrome (t-MDS).

The bone marrow biopsy stained with Perl's Prussian blue shows ringed sideroblasts. They are erythroblasts with iron-laden mitochondria visible as perinuclear granules as shown in the image below.

Myelodysplastic syndrome is a group of clonal stem cell disorders characterized by maturation defects, associated with ineffective hematopoiesis.

It is of two types:

  • Primary MDS - develops slowly, usually after 50 years of age.
  • Secondary or therapy-related MDS (t-MDS) - develops 2 to 8 years after toxic drug or radiation exposure with poor prognosis

Patients usually present with weakness, infections and hemorrhages due to pancytopenia. Both types of MDS have a high risk of transformation to acute myeloid leukemia (AML). However, most frequent and rapid transformation occurs in therapy-related MDS (t-MDS).

VEXAS syndrome (vacuoles, E1 enzyme, X-linked, autoinflammatory, somatic) is a Novel disorder discovered in 2020. It is an adult-onset inflammatory disease with clinical features that bridge rheumatologic & hematologic conditions. VEXAS may be a prototype for new class of “hematoinflammatory diseases.” These diseases would be defined by somatic mutations in hematopoietic cells, systemic inflammation, & potential to evolve into overt myelodysplastic, myeloproliferative, or lymphoproliferative disease.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child presented to you a week after rejoining school after lockdown with fever and the following facial appearance. Which of the following is true regarding this?

choices.text: Patient is non-infectious during rash appearance
PCR assay should be done to confirm the diagnosis
Treatment with Topical steroids is needed

questions.solution:
The given image shows the classical slapped cheek appearance of erythema infectiosum caused by parvovirus B19. During the rash period, the patient is non-infectious..

Parvovirus B19 is a non-enveloped single-stranded DNA virus and usually presents as a respiratory infection, with an erythematous maculopapular rash and arthralgia. The rash starts as prominent erythema of the cheek, popularly known as a slapped cheek appearance. The rash further spreads to the trunk and limbs followed by lymphadenopathy and arthralgia. It is a clinical diagnosis not requiring investigations usually. However in case of pregnant women or with other manifestations an IgM ELISA or PCR assay may be done. It is self-limited and resolves on its own.

Other manifestations of  Parvovirus B19

  • It induces aplastic crisis in sickle cell anemia patients.
  • Infection during the 2nd or 3rd trimester of pregnancy leads to non-immune fetal hydrops.

 

Cutaneous manifestations of COVID:

  • Morbilliform rash - most common cutaneous manifestation. Seen on trunk usually after COVID recovery.
  • Pernio (chillblain) like acral lesions/ COVID toes- erythematous-violaceous or purpuric macules seen without cold exposure. On fingers, toes, lateral aspect of fingers or toes.
  • Livedo reticularis like vascular lesions
  • Retiform purpura/ Necrotic vascular lesions
  • Urticaria
  • Varicella like vesicular eruptions
  • Multisystem inflammatory syndrome in children

 

Related Pearl: Skin rashes: 1st to 6th diseases

1st disease

Measles

2nd disease

Scarlet fever

3rd disease

Rubella

4th disease

Duke’s disease

5th disease

Erythema infectiosum

6th disease

Roseola infantum

questions.text: A patient was diagnosed with renal tubular damage caused by one of his chemotherapeutic drugs. Which drug could it be?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of nephrotoxicity and is one of the dose-limiting toxicity of cisplatin therapy. Cisplatin achieves a high concentration in nephrons. Both direct toxicity and inflammation are responsible for nephrotoxicity. A high concentration of chloride stabilizes cisplatin and reduces nephrotoxicity. Therefore, chloride diuresis is used to reduce nephrotoxicity.

Cisplatin is a platinum coordination complex that enters cells by the high-affinity Cu2+ transporter CTR1 and thus degrade the transporter. Inside the cell, the chloride, cyclohexane, or oxalate ligands of the analogues are displaced by water molecules, yielding a positively charged molecule that reacts with nucleophilic sites on DNA and proteins.

Uses:

  • In combination with bleomycin, etoposide, or with ifosfamide and vinblastine, cures 90% of patients with testicular cancer
  • Used with paclitaxel, induces complete response in the majority of patients with carcinoma of the ovary
  • Cisplatin produces responses in cancers of the bladder, head and neck, cervix, and endometrium
  • All forms of carcinoma of the lung; anal and rectal carcinomas; and neoplasms of childhood.
  • The drug also sensitizes cells to radiation therapy and enhances control of locally advanced lung, esophageal, and head and neck tumors when given with irradiation.

Adverse effects:

  • Dose-dependent nephrotoxicity
  • Ototoxicity- high-frequency hearing loss and tinnitus
  • Peripheral motor and sensory neurotoxicity
  • Anemia
  • Hypomagnesemia
  • Hypocalcemia
  • Hypokalemia
  • Hypophosphatemia
  • AML, usually 4 or more years after treatment

Option B - Streptozotocin use can result in diabetes mellitus due to the destruction of beta cells of the pancreas.

Option C - Methysergide use is associated with retroperitoneal fibrosis.

Option D - Cyclophosphamide causes hemorrhagic cystitis as one of its characteristic side effects.

ANTI-CANCER DRUGS AND THEIR TOXICITIES

DRUG TOXICITY
Cyclophosphamide & Ifosfamide Hemorrhagic cystitis, SIADH
Busulfan Pulmonary fibrosis
Procarbazine

Secondary leukemias

Disulfiram-like reaction

myelosuppression

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presented with cardiac dysrhythmia. On probing, he says he consumed the leaves of the plant shown in the image. What is the active principle of this plant?
questions.solution:
The plant in the image is Digitalis purpurea. Its active principle is digitonin.

Digitalis purpurea contains digitoxin, digitalin, digitonin, and digoxin. It can cause cardiac dysrhythmia in acute toxicity. 

Related Pearl: Plant poisons

Datura stramonium (Jimsonweed) : Flower and fruit are poisonous

Ricinus communis : Seed is poisonous

Digitalis purpurea 

Atropa belladonna

Calotropis gigantea

questions.text: Where can we find the Thornwaldt's cyst?
questions.solution:
Thornwaldt cyst can be found in the midline of the posterior wall of the nasopharynx in the adenoid mass.

  • It is an epithelial-lined median recess found within the adenoid mass and extends from pharyngeal mucosa to the periosteum of the basiocciput.
  • It represents the attachment of notochord to the pharyngeal endoderm during embryonic life.
  • When infected, it may be the cause of persistent postnasal discharge or crusting. Sometimes an abscess can form in the bursa (Thornwaldt’s disease).
  • It is managed surgically by marsupialization of the swelling and complete removal of the lining of the cyst.    

The following is the MRI showing a Thornwald cyst.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy was seen by the optometrist for complaints of blurred vision.  While examining for refractive error, he noticed that the child's corneas were unusually small for his age and referred him for further evaluation. Below what horizontal diameter can a diagnosis of microcornea be made in this child?
questions.solution:
To make a diagnosis of microcornea, in this child, the diameter of the cornea should be less than 10 mm.

Micro-cornea

  • Horizontal corneal diameter is 10 mm or less (over 2 years of age) or less than 9 mm (in the newborn).
  • There may be hypermetropia and a shallow anterior chamber but other dimensions are normal.

Megalocornea

  • Horizontal corneal diameter is 12 mm or more (up to 2 years of age) or 13 mm or more (if age >2 years)
  • There is typically high myopia and astigmatism, but normal corrected visual acuity.
  • Usually X-linked recessive; 90% of affected individuals are male.

Cornea plana

  • The cornea is flatter than normal, i.e., the radius of curvature is larger.
  • There is a corresponding reduction in refractive power, resulting in high hypermetropia.

Keratectasia

  • It is characterized by a protuberance between the eyelids caused by a severely opacified, and sometimes vascularized, cornea.
  • It is often associated with raised intraocular pressure as well as intrauterine keratitis.
  • Usually unilateral

Microphthalmos

  • Microphthalmia is a condition in which the entire eye is small, with an axial length at least two standard deviations below the mean for age.
  • It may or may not be associated with ocular dysgenesis.

Nanophthalmos

  • In nanophthalmos (simple microphthalmos), the entire eye is small, but is structurally normal; 
  • It is usually associated with hypermetropia and strabismus

Anophthalmos: Anophthalmos (anophthalmia) refers to the complete absence of any visible globe structure.

questions.text:
In an urban area in the state of Madhya Pradesh, a primigravida goes for institutional delivery after being motivated by an ASHA worker. What are the benefits they will receive (in terms of money in rupees) under the Janani Suraksha Yojana?

ASHA- Accredited social health activist
questions.solution:
According to Janani Suraksha Yojana (JSY) scheme, the mother will receive 1000 rupees and the ASHA worker will receive 400 rupees.

Janani Suraksha Yojana (JSY) is a program under the National Rural Health Mission (NRHM), whose aim is to reduce maternal mortality by encouraging delivery in government health facilities. Under the scheme, a financial incentive is also provided for giving birth in a government health facility. 

The Accredited Social Health Activist (ASHA) is the link between pregnant women and health institutions. She is responsible for making institutional antenatal and postnatal care available. 

States are divided into low-performing and high-performing on the basis of institutional delivery rate. (The 10 low-performing states (LPS) with a low institutional delivery rate are Uttar Pradesh, Uttarakhand, Madhya Pradesh, Jharkhand, Bihar, Rajasthan, Chattisgarh, Odisha, Assam, and Jammu & Kashmir. All the other states are high-performing states) (HPS).

The incentives under JSY are as follows:

Category  Rural area Urban area
LPS

Mother package: 1400/-
ASHA's package:600/-
Total:2000/-

 Mother package: 1000/-
ASHA's package:400/-
Total:1400/-
HPS Mother package: 700/-
ASHA's package:600/-
Total:1300/-		 Mother package: 600/-
ASHA's package:400/-
Total:1000/-

Under this scheme, the cost of cesarean section and management of obstetric complications is also subsidized, up to Rs 1500 per delivery to the government institutions, where government specialists are not present.

questions.text: A patient with Wilm's tumor undergoes renal transplantation. He is currently on corticosteroid therapy to prevent organ rejection. All of the following vaccinations could be given to this patient except?
questions.solution:
Intra-nasal/ nasal spray influenza vaccine is a live attenuated vaccine, therefore it is contraindicated in this patient as he is immunosuppressed.

Live vaccines are prepared from live or wild attenuated organisms. They are repeatedly passed through tissue cultures or chick embryos in the laboratory. With this, they lose their ability to induce full-blown infection in an individual but retain their immunogenicity. It should not be administered to patients with immunodeficiency diseases, lymphoma, leukaemia, or other malignancies. It is also not recommended in individuals on treatment with corticosteroids, antimetabolites, and alkylating agents. Unless the risk of infection exceeds the risk of harm, it is contraindicated in pregnancy. 

Live- attenuated influenza vaccine is approved for use in otherwise healthy individuals between age of 2 years and 49 years. Because the risk of transmission of the live-attenuated vaccine virus to immunocompromised individuals is unknown, it should not be used in household members of immunosuppressed individuals, health care workers, or others with close contact with immunosuppressed persons.

Intramuscular influenza vaccine is an inactivated vaccine, which can be given in the immunocompromised.

Other options:

Option A: Diptheria-pertussis-tetanus (DPT) vaccine is a combination toxoid vaccine. The toxins produced by diphtheria and tetanus bacilli are detoxicated and used to prepare the vaccine. They are highly efficacious and safe. The killed whole organism is used for the pertussis component. 

Option B: Hepatitis B vaccine is a recombinant vaccine. It is produced by inserting a viral gene segment into a yeast cell. It does not contain viral DNA and will not produce an infection.

Option D: Inactivated polio vaccine is a killed vaccine. As the organism cannot grow in a vaccinated individual, it can be given to an immunodeficient individual.

questions.text: A child was encouraged by his parents to follow a healthy lifestyle to prevent obesity. What level of prevention is adopted in this scenario?
questions.solution:
Primordial prevention is adopted in this scenario.

The emergence of risk factors for obesity is prevented by encouraging the child to follow a healthy lifestyle from an early age. This reduces the probability of developing obesity in the future.

Primordial prevention is the prevention of the emergence of risk factors in populations in which they have not yet appeared. Most adult health problems have their origins in childhood. Efforts are directed toward discouraging children from adopting harmful lifestyles. The main intervention in primordial prevention is individual and mass education.

Other options:

Option A: Primary prevention is the action taken before the onset of the disease to prevent the possibility that a disease will ever occur. Here, intervention is initiated in the pre-pathogenesis phase of a disease. It is accomplished by population strategy and high-risk strategy. Examples of primary prevention are immunization and sanitizing hands.

Option C: Secondary prevention is halting the progress of a disease which has already occurred. It aims to halt the progress at its incipient (initial) stage and preventing complications. Intervention is initiated in the early pathogenesis phase. Measures like early diagnosis and treatment are used to arrest the disease progression. Examples of secondary prevention are pap smears for early detection of cervical cancer and mammography to pick up breast cancer.

Option D: Tertiary prevention is the action taken to limit impairment and promote rehabilitation of patients in case of irreversible damage. Intervention is done in the late pathogenesis phase. An example is rehabilitation by providing walking aid for the crippled.

Related Pearl: Levels of Prevention

Level

Primordial

Primary

Secondary

Tertiary

Phase of disease

Underlying socio-economic & environmental conditions leading to causation

Specific causal or risk factors

Early stage of disease

Late stage of disease

Reduce the incidence of disease

Reduce prevalence by shortening duration

Reduce number and impact of complications

Actions

Inhibition of emergence of socio-economic, environmental and behavioural conditions

Protection of personal and community health by eliminating risks

Soften the impact of long-term disease and disability, minimize suffering

Modes of Intervention

Health education

Health promotion and specific protection

 

Diagnosis and treatment

Disability limitation and rehabilitation

Targets

Total population or select groups

Total population or high risk individuals/groups

 

Individuals/ Patients

Patients

questions.text: A male patient is suspected to have pheochromocytoma. He has all the 3 symptoms making up the clinical triad of pheochromocytoma. Which of the following is not a part of this triad?
questions.solution:
The clinical triad of pheochromocytoma includes the following symptoms:

  • Headache
  • Profuse sweating
  • Palpitation (due to tachycardia)

Hypertension is the most predominant sign of pheochromocytoma. Though intermittent hypertension is a classical feature, sustained hypertension is also common.

Related Pearl: Pheochromocytoma

Features:

  • When pheochromocytoma is associated with the MEN syndrome it is rarely malignant.
  • Phaeochromocytomas are greyish-pink on the cut surface and are usually highly vascularised.
  • Zellbalen cells and nuclei with salt and pepper chromatin are seen.

Factors indicating more chances of malignancy:

  • An increased PASS (phaeochromocytoma of the adrenal gland scale score)
  • High number of Ki-67-positive cells
  • Vascular invasion or a breached capsule

Diagnosis:

  • Urinary catecholamine and VMA level assay are most sensitive screening test.
  • MRI is the IOC.
  • Biopsy and CT Contrast scan are contraindicated in order to avoid Hypertensive crisis.

Treatment:

  • Adrenalectomy is preferred TOC.
  • Size<5 cm -  Laparoscopic adrenalectomy
  • Preop Alpha blockers should be given
  • Mitotane should be started as adjuvant or palliative treatment

questions.text: Which of the following drugs reduce mortality in a patient with heart failure?
questions.solution:
Metoprolol is a beta-blocker that is found to reduce mortality in a patient with heart failure.

Beta-blockers have been shown to prolong survival, prevent arrhythmia, and improve symptoms of heart failure and left ventricular ejection fraction, especially in patients with chronic heart failure.

The drugs which reduce mortality in patients with heart failure are :

  • ACE inhibitors
  • Angiotensin receptor blockers (ARBs)
  • Angiotensin receptor neprilysin inhibitor (ARNI)
  • Beta-blockers
  • Mineralocorticoid receptor antagonists
    • Spironolactone
    • Eplerenone
  • Hydralazine + isosorbide dinitrate.

Related Pearl: Drugs used in heart failure

Drugs used in acute decompensated heart failure:

Drugs used for rapid symptom relief

questions.text: What is the finding in the given EEG of an infant?
questions.solution:
Hypsarrhythmia is an abnormal interictal pattern which consists of diffuse, giant slow waves with a chaotic background of irregular, multifocal spikes and sharp waves. During the clinical spasm, there is a marked suppression of the EEG background (the electrodecremental response).

Hypsarrhythmias are usually seen in epileptic spasms. These are characterized by a briefly sustained flexion or extension of predominantly proximal muscles, including truncal muscles.

The table given below shows the EEG features seen in various seizure disorders.

Disease Typical EEG feature
Lennox-Gastaut syndrome 1.5-2.5 Hz spike and polyspike bursts in sleep
Absence seizures 3 Hz spike and slow-wave (spike and dome pattern)
Juvenile myoclonic epilepsy 4-5 Hz spike
West syndrome Hypsarrhythmia (high-voltage waves with chaotic background)

questions.text: A young woman presents with skin rashes shown in the image below. She also complains of  easy bruisability and bleeding from gums. Her CBC report revealed platelet count 15,000/µL, normal RBC and WBC counts. Her peripheral smear was normal. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis in this patient is immune thrombocytopenic purpura.

The given image showing petechiae and the clinical scenario are suggestive of a bleeding disorder. CBC shows isolated thrombocytopenia and peripheral smear does not reveal any hemolysis. Hence, the other conditions are ruled out. 

Immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP) is an acquired disorder with autoantibodies against platelet membrane glycoproteins IIb-IIIa or Ib-IX. It can either be primary (idiopathic) or secondary to autoimmune conditions like SLE or infections like HIV and hepatitis C.

It presents with features of mucocutaneous bleeding. CBC shows isolated thrombocytopenia and peripheral smear does not reveal any hemolysis. 

Acute ITP Chronic ITP
Common in children Common in adults (females > males)
Associated with an antecedent viral infection Not associated with antecedent infection
Spontaneous remission within 6 months in most cases Spontaneous remission is not usually seen

Other options:

Options A and B- HUS and TTP are microangiopathies. They are associated with hemolysis which is not seen in this patient.

Option D- DIC is a coagulopathy usually associated with sepsis and the peripheral smear shows fragmented RBCs.

questions.text: A patient who was admitted after a road traffic accident (RTA) is put on mechanical ventilation. He opens his eyes on verbal commands and both pupils are well reactive. He moves all 4 limbs spontaneously. What is his GCS score
questions.solution:
The GCS score in this patient can be documented as Eyes-3, Verbal-NT, Motor-6, and Pupil-0.

  • Eye-opening to verbal command - 3 
  • In endotracheal intubation, the verbal response cannot be tested. It is documented as NT.
  • Movement of all 4 limbs spontaneously - 6
  • Both the pupils are reactive- 0

The total GCS score is not recorded since one of the components is non-testable (NT).

The GCS-P is calculated by subtracting the Pupil Reactivity Score (PRS) from the Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) total score:

GCS-P = GCS - PRS

Related Pearl: Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS)

GCS Score

  • 13-15 represent mild brain injury
  • 9-12 represent moderate brain injury
  • scores ≤8 represent severe brain injury 

Head Injury Severity: Clinical classification

To painful stimulus 2

Inappropriate words only 3
Sounds only 2
No sounds 1

Non-testable

 NT

 

Motor Response Score
Obeys commands 6
Localizes to pain 5
Withdrawal/flexion 4
Abnormal flexion/Decorticate posturing  3
Extension/Decerebrate posturing  2
No motor response 1

Non-testable

 NT

Minimum value: 3

Maximum value: 15

  • The motor score, is the best predictor of neurological outcome.
  • If an area cannot be assessed, no numerical score is given for that region, and it is considered “non-testable." (NT)
  • In case of endotracheal intubation or tracheostomy, the verbal component of the score is denoted as NT.

 

NOTE: 

A new parameter, "pupil reactivity score" has been added to GCS, and now, it is referred to as GCS-P.

P stands for "Pupils unreactive to light"

Pupils Unreactive to light Score
Both pupils 2
One pupil 1 
Neither  0

The pupillary score is subtracted from the GCS score to give the final value. Therefore, the range of GCS-P is 1–15.

questions.text: The sign shown in the given image represents _____
questions.solution:
In gallstones, the above computed tomography (CT) image shows the seagull/Mercedes-Benz sign.

  • A skillfully taken plain X-ray image of the gallbladder shows radiopaque gallstones in 10% of the patients.
  • Rarely, the centre of a stone may contain radiolucent gas in a triradiate or biradiate fissure, and this gives rise to characteristic dark shapes on a radiograph—the "Mercedes–Benz" or "seagull" sign.

questions.text: A 24-year-old lady in her third week postpartum complains of pain in her left breast. She also complains of mild fever, headache, and nausea. Examination reveals a tender breast with red, hot, and flushed overlying skin. There is no fluctuant swelling or discharge. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical picture of a lactating mother presenting with breast pain, fever, headache, nausea, and tender breast with red, hot, and flushed overlying skin points towards a diagnosis of acute mastitis.

The most common organism involved in acute mastitis is Staphylococcus aureus. Other organisms involved are Staphylococcus epidermidis, and Streptococci viridans. The source of organisms is the infant’s nose and throat. It usually occurs during the first 2–4 weeks postpartum.

Clinical features:

  • Generalized malaise
  • Headache
  • Nausea and vomiting
  • Fever with chills
  • Severe pain and, non-fluctuant swelling.
  • The overlying skin is red, hot, and flushed, and feels tense and tender

Microscopic examination of breast milk shows leucocytes >106/mL and bacterial count >103/mL. It might lead to the formation of a breast abscess.

Management:

  • Breast support and analgesics
  • Breastfeeding is continued. The infected side is emptied manually with each feed.
  • Dicloxacillin is the drug of choice
  • Erythromycin is given to patients who are allergic to penicillin

Other options:

Option A - Breast engorgement occurs due to exaggerated normal venous and lymphatic engorgement of the breasts which precedes lactation. It is characterized by bilateral breast tenderness and swelling typically present 24 to 72 hours post-partum, peaks 3 to 5 days after delivery and resolves spontaneously. Antibiotics are not indicated. Treatment is by cold compresses and analgesics.

Option B - A galactocele is a milk-filled cavity in the breast of a woman who is usually lactating. It can be caused due to lactation problems, prolactin stimulation by drugs, or duct obstruction. It presents as a palpable, round, well-circumscribed, and freely mobile mass with no fever, pain, or inflammation. It is usually subareolar and unilateral.

Option C - Breast abscess is usually suspected when there is no response to treatment for mastitis in 48-72 hours. It is also characterised by brawny oedema over the affected area, fluctuant lump. Management includes sonography-guided needle aspiration under local anaesthesia. Antibiotics and pumping of the affected breast are also done. Incision and drainage of the abscess are done in cases not responding to aspiration.

questions.text: Identify the following instrument
questions.solution:
The instrument shown is a harmonic scalpel. It is an instrument that uses ultrasonic energy to cut tissues while simultaneously coagulating them.

The scalpel vibrates in the 20000–50000 Hz range and cuts through tissues, achieving hemostasis by sealing vessels and tissues by means of protein denaturation using vibration rather than heat.

Cutting is a mode of diathermy/electrosurgery. The cut current is a low-voltage, continuous waveform. Cutting occurs when sufficient heat is applied to the tissue to cause cell water to explode into steam.

Coagulation is the sealing of blood vessels. In coagulation, a heating effect leads to cell death by dehydration and protein denaturation.

A blend is a combination of cutting and coagulation.

Other options:

Option B: LigaSure vessel sealing system (shown below) is a bipolar apparatus for sealing vascular tissue. It applies a high coaptive pressure during the generation of tissue temperature under 1000°C, hydrogen cross-links are first ruptured and then renatured, resulting in a vascular seal that has high tensile strength.

Related Pearl: Diathermy/Cautery:

Features Monopolar Bipolar
Flow of current

Cautery pencil –> tissue –> cautery pad –> machine/ground

Hence more chance of burns

Only between tips of the instrument

Hence less chance of burns
Modes

Cutting – Low voltage, high amplitude, continuous waveforms

Coagulation – Alternate waveforms (Bursts)

Dessication – Low power

Fulguration – High power

 Only coagulation
Dissipation

More thermal dissipation of current

Hence can cause damage to nerves and other vital structures

Less lateral dissipation of current

Hence safer in procedures closer to vital structures

questions.text: The following image shows ______

choices.text: Brandt Andrews method of placental separation

questions.solution:
The given image shows the Duncan method of placental separation.

Schultze Duncan
Separation begins from center of placenta to periphery. Separation begins from periphery to centre.
Blood does not escape externally, as the blood pours into membrane sac. Blood escapes from the vagina as the blood collects between the membranes and uterine wall.
  • Brandt Andrew method is a maneuver of expressing the placenta from the uterus in the third stage of labor. 
  • One hand grasps the umbilical cord while the other is placed on the mother's abdomen with the fingers over the anterior surface of the uterus.
  • While the hand on the abdomen is pressed backward and slightly upward, the other applies gentle traction on the cord.

Image A - Schultze, B - Mathew Duncan

questions.text: Which of the following is the most dependent part of a female?
questions.solution:
The rectouterine pouch, which is also called the pouch of Douglas is the most dependent part of a female.

Peritoneum of the female pelvis:

In females, the peritoneum covers the anterior and anterolateral surfaces of the rectum, uterus, and urinary bladder. Spaces found in the female pelvis are:

Pararectal fossae: Present on either side of the rectum. They are limited laterally by the peritoneum that covers the uterosacral ligaments. 

Paravesical fossae: Present on either side of the bladder. It is limited laterally by the peritoneum which covers the round ligament of the uterus.

Rectouterine pouch (pouch of Douglas): The peritoneum which covers the anterior surface of the rectum is reflected anteriorly to cover the posterior surface of the posterior fornix of the vagina and the uterus, forming a rectouterine pouch.

Vesicouterine pouch: The peritoneum covering the fundus and body of the uterus, is reflected anteriorly to cover the posterosuperior surface of the bladder forming a vesicouterine pouch.

Ovarian fossa: It is a shallow depression in the peritoneal lining of the lateral pelvic wall between the peritoneal ridges. It is formed by the obliterated umbilical arteries anteriorly, the ureter posteriorly, and the external iliac vessels above. It lies behind the lateral attachment of the broad ligament and contains the ovary in nulliparous females.

questions.text: All are true about the treatment of Respiratory Distress Syndrome with surfactant except ______.

choices.text: In neonates with RDS who fail CPAP, treatment with endotracheal surfactant should be initiated immediately after intubation.
It is given prophylactically to all neonates at < 31 weeks gestation.
It can be given as rescue treatment (when RDS actually develops).
Repeated dosing is given every 6-12 hr for a total of 2 to 4 doses.

questions.solution:
Surfactant is given prophylactically to all neonates < 28 weeks, not 31 weeks irrespective of presence or absence of Respiratory Distress Syndrome (RDS).

Surfactant therapy in RDS:

  • Surfactant is indicated in all infants with severe RDS.
  • Given as rescue treatment when CPAP fails in moderate RDS.
  • Route of administration is intratracheal.

questions.text: A type 1 diabetic mother is on magnesium sulfate infusion post-cesarean section for preeclampsia. She develops delirium and is drowsy. She has a respiratory rate of 10/min, random blood glucose level of 240 mg/dL, oliguria, and bilaterally absent knee reflex. What is the cause of her condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and examination finding of bilaterally absent knee reflex following magnesium sulfate (MgSO4) administration for preeclampsia suggest the cause of her condition to be magnesium sulfate toxicity. 

MgSO4 is used as an anticonvulsant in the management of eclampsia and as prophylaxis in severe preeclampsia. It can also be used as a tocolytic to stop preterm labor. The therapeutic level of magnesium in eclampsia is 4–7 mEq/L. 

Patients must be monitored for magnesium toxicity:

  • Loss of deep tendon reflexes
  • Decreased respiratory rate <12/min
  • Urine output <30 mL/h
  • Chest pain and heart block 
  • Visual changes, flushing, muscle paralysis, and drowsiness

Measurement of serum magnesium levels is indicated to monitor magnesium toxicity if serum creatinine >1.0 mg/dL.

Management of magnesium toxicity is as follows:

  • Stop magnesium therapy
  • Estimation of serum magnesium and creatinine levels
  • Intravenous injection of calcium gluconate 10 mL (10% solution) 

The two commonly used MgSO4 regimens are described below: 

Regimen

Loading Dose

Maintenance Dose

Intramuscular (Pritchard)

4 g (20% solution) IV over 3–5 minutes, followed by 10 g (50%) deep IM (5 g in each buttock)

5 g (50%) IM 4 hourly in the alternate buttock

Intravenous (Zuspan or Sibai)

4 g IV slow over 15–20 minute

1–2 g/h IV infusion

Repeated/maintenance dose IM injections of magnesium sulfate are continued only under the following conditions:

  • The patellar reflex is present
  • Respiration is not depressed
  • Urine output >30 mL/h

Other options:

Option B: Pregnant women with diabetic ketoacidosis present with hyperventilation (Kussmaul breathing) and their blood glucose level is around 380 mg/dL.

Option C: Eclampsia patients present with generalized tonic-clonic convulsions.

Option D: Diabetes insipidus patients present with polyuria and polydipsia.

questions.text: A 55 year old female complains of lower backache. The radiographic image of her lumbosacral spine is given below. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above image depicts ballooning of disc spaces leading to biconcave shape of vertebral body known as ‘Cod fish appearance’, classically seen in osteoporosis. 

It is caused due to the reduction in the strength of the bone that leads to an increased risk of fractures. WHO defines osteoporosis as a T score less than -2.5. It is the gold standard to assess bone mineral density.

Other radiological features of osteoporosis:

  • Loss of vertical height of vertebra due to collapse
  • Ground glass appearance of bones especially in the bones like pelvis
  • Loss of cortical bone (picture frame vertebrae) and trabecular bone (ghost vertebrae)
  • Loss of trabeculae in proximal femur area.

questions.text: A mother started to feel sad and tearful over the first two weeks following childbirth. She felt overwhelmed by the responsibilities of nursing her baby and changing diapers and waking up in the middle of the night. She felt that she was a failure as a mother. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of postpartum blues. 

It is characterized by a labile mood, sadness, and subjective confusion. It is thought to be due to changes in hormone levels, the stress of childbirth, and anxiety about the responsibilities of motherhood. This usually resolves spontaneously. 

If symptoms last longer than 2 weeks, an evaluation for postpartum depression is needed.

Disorders and features Incidence and timeline Harmful thoughts Treatment

Postpartum blues:

Depressed affect, tearfulness and fatigue

30-75%

Starts 2-3 days after delivery. Resolves within 10 days.

 No thoughts of harming the baby Support and follow up

Postpartum depression:

Depressed affect, anxiety and poor concentration

10-15%

Starts within 12 weeks from delivery and persists for ≥ 2 weeks. 

 Thoughts of harming the baby often present CBT and SSRIs 

Postpartum psychosis:

Mood-congruent delusions, hallucinations

 0.1-0.2% Thoughts of harming the baby or self Hospitalization, atypical antipsychotics and ECT for refractory cases

questions.text: The type of laryngoscope blade shown in the given image is:
questions.solution:
The given image shows Miller laryngoscopic blade.

Miller is a straight blade laryngoscope, used in:

  • Neonates, infants and young children
  • Adults with short thyromental distance and long floppy epiglottis.

Laryngoscopic blades can be

  • Straight blade, Miller
  • Curved blade, Macintosh

Advantage of curved blade:

  • Greater room available for the passage for an endotracheal tube
  • Less damage to the teeth

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy presented with itchy skin lesions on his face. for the past 3 days. On examination, there are erythematous lesions near the mouth with honey-yellow crusting, as shown in the image given below. Identify the condition.
questions.solution:
The above image showing erythematous lesions with honey-colored crusts is suggestive of impetigo contagiosa (a.k.a non-bullous impetigo).

Impetigo is a type of bacterial skin infection, commonly caused by Staphylococcus aureus and group A beta-hemolytic Streptococcus pyogenes. It is self-limiting, has an incubation period of 4-10 days, and lasts for about two-three weeks.

Topical antibiotics are preferable to oral antibiotics for limited impetigo. Three topical antibiotics recommended for impetigo are mupirocin 2%, retapamulin 1% ointment, and fusidic acid.

Option B: The lesions of the molluscum contagiosum are shiny, white, and hemispherical. It is umbilicated with a central pore. It is caused by poxvirus. 

The below image shows the lesions seen in Molluscum contagiosum.

Option C: Herpes simplex virus type 1 (HSV-1) is classically associated with facial infections causing herpes labialis or cold sore.  Below image shows small, closely grouped vesicles on an inflamed base which is characteristic of herpes labialis.

Option D : Cellulitis is an acute subacute or chronic inflammation of loose connective tissue usually due to a bacterial infection. It presents as a diffuse swelling associated with pain and tenderness.The given image shows how the edges of the lesion in cellulitis are diffuse.

Related Pearl: Skin and soft tissue lesions caused by Streptococcus

Streptococcus causes a variety of skin and soft tissue infections. These include:

a. Impetigo- Infection of superficial layers of the skin. It presents as superficial vesicles which break down and are then encrusted by honey-colored scab. It usually occurs in children.

The given image shows impetigo:

 

b. Erysipelas- Infection of the superficial epidermis. It presents as an erythematous raised lesion with sharply demarcated edges that differentiate it from the surrounding skin. 

The given image shows erysipelas- note the clear demarcation at the nasolabial folds seen in facial erysipelas.

 

c. Cellulitis- Infection of the skin and subcutaneous tissue. It presents with erythema and edema. It can be differentiated from erysipelas by - i. Erysipelas is a raised lesion whereas cellulitis is not, ii. Cellulitis is poorly demarcated from the surrounding skin whereas erysipelas is clearly demarcated.

The given image shows cellulitis:

 

d. Necrotizing fasciitis- Infection involving the fascial planes. It presents with dark areas of necrosis, erythema, and edema.

The given image shows necrotizing fasciitis with areas of erythema and necrosis:

 

d. Myositis and myonecrosis- Infection of the muscle.

The given image shows necrotizing myositis:

questions.text: A newborn is seen to have an abnormal lump in the lower back. Identify the condition from the MRI given below.
questions.solution:
The MRI given represents meningocele. 

Meningocele involves the midline protrusion of the meninges. A fluctuant midline mass, that may transilluminate is present in the lower back along the vertebral column. Meningomyelocele involves the protrusion of the spinal cord with the meningeal covering. Neurological dysfunction is more common in these open defects.

Spina bifida occulta refers to fusion defects of the posterior part of the vertebral body. There is no associated protrusion of the spinal cord or meninges. These neonates are usually asymptomatic, without any neurological signs. They present only with a tuft of hair over the lower back. 

The image below shows (from left to right) spina bifida occulta, meningocele, and meningomyelocele-

questions.text: 4R’s of Radiotherapy are:
questions.solution:
In general, success or failure of standard clinical radiation treatment is determined by the 4 R’s of radiobiology: repair of DNA damage, redistribution or ressortment of cells in the cell cycle, repopulation, and reoxygenation of hypoxic tumor areas.

5th R of radiotherapy is radiosensitivity.
